For when a crop plant is infested with insects and other pests and needs some work to remove them

ENGLISH: This crop has been afflicted by an excessive number of aphids and other insects which need to be removed by a {{PROFESSION.FARMER}} before it can flourish again. Not removing the pests in time could mean that this crop dies!

NOTES: E.g. “Progress towards harvest: 30%”

ENGLISH: Destroyed by prolonged exposure to rain

NOTES: Used when the player clicks on an area they have not discovered yet
This is a made-up fantasy food

ENGLISH: This is an infamously tough bread which is so hard and practically inedible that it takes a very long time to turn mouldy. The human explorer J. A. Moffatt once described eating it as “akin to chewing gravel that has been dredged from a swamp”. Fortunately most dwarves don’t seem to mind.

NOTES: Actually just to describe “wheat” as a foodstuff, not specifically bread

ENGLISH: Fuel is required in the production of metal, both by the {{FURNITURE.BLOOMERY_FURNACE}} and the {{FURNITURE.FORGE}}.
A {{PROFESSION.CHEF}} works here to turn {{RESOURCE.FLOUR.SACK.PLURAL}} into {{INGREDIENT.DOUGH}}.

NOTES: For the baking of bread

ENGLISH: A {{PROFESSION.CHEF}} bakes loaves here using prepared {{INGREDIENT.DOUGH}}.
A beer barrel is on the way
This is where fermented {{LIQUID.BEER}} is served from.

NOTES: A simple type of furnace to smelt metal from ore

ENGLISH: A {{PROFESSION.BLACKSMITH}} uses this hand-operated furnace to turn {{RESOURCE.ORE.CRUSHED.PLURAL}} and {{FUEL.SACK}} into {{MATERIAL_TYPE.METAL.ADJECTIVE}} {{RESOURCE.METAL.INGOT.PLURAL}}.
This is used to produce the final wort (unfermented beer) using {{VEGETABLE.HOPS}} and wort from the {{FURNITURE.MASH_TUN}}.
Most wooden items and tools are produced here, such as {{PRODUCT.BUCKET.PLURAL}} and {{PRODUCT.BARREL.PLURAL}}.

NOTES: A large metal pot for cooking (common with Halloween)

ENGLISH: A cauldron is used to serve a large quantity of soup to hungry settlers. The soup is produced in a {{ROOMS.KITCHEN}} before being moved to a {{ROOMS.FEASTING_HALL}} for serving.
This is a pile of {{RESOURCE.LOGS.PLURAL}} covered with {{MATERIAL_TYPE.EARTH}} and slowly burned to produce {{ORE.CHARCOAL.NOUN}}, which can then be used as {{FUEL.SACK}}.
A coke oven converts {{ORE.BITUMINOUS_COAL.NOUN}} into {{ORE.COKE.NOUN}} so that it can be used as {{FUEL.SACK}}.

NOTES: E.g. “Granite stonemason workbench”
Used to display how long a mushroom log submerged in water needs to be “shocked” for

ENGLISH: Waiting to be injected with mushroom spawn

NOTES: A very large table for a feast

ENGLISH: With a {{FURNITURE.CHAIR}} in place, your settlers will enjoy their meals at this table.
This is where {{LIQUID.HOPPED_WORT}} is fermented into {{LIQUID.BEER}}.

NOTES: This is a table with a hand-operated flour mill stone on top

ENGLISH: The gristmill grinds {{VEGETABLE.WHEAT}} into {{RESOURCE.FLOUR.SACK.NOUN}} so that it can be used by a {{PROFESSION.CHEF}}.
This is where a {{PROFESSION.BLACKSMITH}} works with {{MATERIAL_TYPE.METAL.ADJECTIVE}} {{RESOURCE.METAL.INGOT.PLURAL}} and {{FUEL.SACK}} to craft items and weapons.
A hastily-dug grave for deceased settlers that can only be placed in {{MATERIAL_TYPE.EARTH}}.

NOTES: Simple piece of furniture in a kitchen used to hold ingredients on top of it

ENGLISH: An area to store ingredients for a {{PROFESSION.CHEF}} to cook soup.
A lantern provides light – this does not currently have an in-game effect.
Here brewers steep barley and then dry it out using a kiln to produce malt.
This is used to produce wort (unfermented beer) from milled malt and water.
A log that has been injected with {{INGREDIENT.MUSHROOM.SPAWN.PLURAL}} to produce several harvests of delicious, juicy mushrooms.

NOTES: This is a trough of water used to immerse mushroom logs in for a period of time

ENGLISH: After innoculation, a {{FURNITURE.MUSHROOM_LOG}} is placed in this tank to “shock” the mushroom colony and encourage it to grow mushrooms.
Raw {{RESOURCE.ORE.UNREFINED.PLURAL}} is crushed to a more workable size so that it can be used in a {{FURNITURE.BLOOMERY_FURNACE}}.

NOTES: A pillar used to support a roof

ENGLISH: A pillar is required to stop large mined-out areas from collapsing. An area of 7x7 tiles that have been mined without any pillars or other supports in place will eventually collapse.

NOTES: A stone tomb

ENGLISH: This elaborate stone container is the final resting place of a deceased settler.

NOTES: A table used to hold food for serving

ENGLISH: {{PRODUCT.BREAD.LOAF.PLURAL}} are placed here for serving after being baked in a {{FURNITURE.BAKING_OVEN}}.
A bed is the best place for a comfortable night’s rest.
A water barrel is a place for your settlers to get a thirst-quenching drink, rather than having to find a natural water source like the river.
A {{PROFESSION.WOODCUTTER}} works here to turn {{RESOURCE.LOGS.PLURAL}} into {{RESOURCE.PLANKS.PLURAL}}.
A violet-hued variety of quartz. Ancient humans believed it could magically protect them from becoming too drunk. For this reason it is not very popular in dwarven culture.
An opal-like gemstone which has a red to green iridescence. It is known as the “hunting stone” and amulets made from it are meant to bring good luck to a hunt.

A cyan-coloured variety of beryl. Some humans believe it offers magical protection against the dangers of the seas. This is because an ancient mage used a combination of sky and ice magic to protect trading ships during the age of darkness.
Also known as red beryl, it is a very rare gemstone. It is often confused for a red-coloured emerald.
An ore of mercury which is often used in jewellery due to its deep-red hue. It is also used to produce the dye known as vermillion.
A yellowish variety of quartz. It is the gemstone most similar in colour to gold, so most dwarves think citrine is lucky.
The hardest known material and one of the most important of the seven heavenly stones. Diamonds are the most condensed form of the neutral element known as “spirit” or “aether”.
A vibrant green variety of beryl. It is thought that engraving on an emerald brings great misfortune. Emeralds are closely related to elemental life and associated magic.
Garnets cover a variety of minerals used as gemstones, all with a deep red colour. Some garnet gems are actually a condensed form of elemental fire.
A mineral with a light-green colour often used for decoration. Also, elves have been known to use jade to produce medicine which can cure ailments of the gut.
An impure variety of silica which can occur in several colours, but most commonly red. Jasper is favoured as a decoration material by orcs due to its variety.
A rock which shines with a typically light-blue iridescence. Rarer specimens can reflect a wide range of colours.
A rock with a brilliant deep blue hue which is used as a precious stone.
A mineral which can be polished into beads for use in jewellery. These beads can by dyed into many different colours.
Thought to be formed by moonlight captured in rock, which makes this gemstone a favourite of the elves.
A rose-coloured variety of beryl. It was named after being popularised by a particularly wealthy merchant in the age of myth.
A form of silica infused with the magic of the oceans, which makes this a favourite of sailors and fishermen.
A very rare gemstone which is often identified as an off-colour sapphire. The crystals are naturally hexagonal in shape and a favourite of tacticians.
Found in varying shades of red to pink. It is not as hard as most gemstones making it a poor choice for rings and other high-impact jewellery.
The purest form of quartz. Rock crystals often feature in magical artifacts as they are a condensed form of the element of ice.
One of the seven heavenly stones, rubies are the element of fire condensed into a solid form.
Often believed to protect the wearer from the attention of daemons, sapphires are much sought-after by mages for use in sky and air-based magic.
Often confused with heavenly stones like true rubies and sapphires, spinels are a lesser form of magic-infused gem which can be associated with any of the elements, depending on colour.
A rare gemstone that can alternate between blue and violet. It is thought to be formed from the material body of a dead god.

Sometimes confused with the more common {{GEM.CITRINE.NOUN}} gem, topaz can be found in several colours but most commonly a yellowish brown. It was first discovered on an island which no longer exists.
Often found alongside {{ORE.CASSITERITE.ADJECTIVE}} ore. It is sometimes associated with earth magic.
A blue-green mineral often used in decorations. It is thought to bring good luck to the bearer. It is often infused with the element of earth.

The selected language translation is currently incomplete and will be missing some text. A fallback language will be used.
You have selected a different set of mods to be applied to the game. These will be applied when the game is next restarted.
One or more mods are incompatible with this version of the game and have been deactivated. You can check for updates in the mods menu.

ENGLISH: You must restart the game for this change to take effect
You already have a saved game for the settlement {{name}}. Starting a new game will overwrite the existing save file. Are you sure you want to continue?
A name for the settlement must be specified.

This is an early alpha version of King under the Mountain. There are many, many features still to be added, and bugs are to be expected. In a future update you will be able to use this screen to customise your starting settlers, resources and even map and gameplay settings. Please join our Discord community to report any bugs you find or offer feedback, so we can work together to guide King under the Mountain to become the best possible version of itself. Thank you for playing!
Click here to join our Discord community

ENGLISH: Slept in a spacious, private bedroom
This view allows you to see which tiles are outside with no roof above them (light blue), and those which have had a roof built overhead (dark brown).
You can use the {{GUI.ROOFING.ADD}} and {{GUI.CANCEL_LABEL}} options to queue up roofing to be constructed, and {{GUI.DECONSTRUCT_LABEL}} to remove any existing roof tiles.
A roof can only be constructed within 3 tiles of a wall or {{FURNITURE.PILLAR}}.
A fire has started! Extinguish it quickly before it spreads.
You can use the {{GUI.ORDERS.EXTINGUISH_FLAMES}} order to douse the flames with water. Any settlers on fire will attempt to put themselves out.
You can use this menu to change the priority of jobs and tasks, so that higher priority jobs will be assigned before lower priority jobs.
While the Priority menu is open, the priority icons are shown in the game world where there is a job or task to be performed, or where a room or item of furniture may create jobs in the future.
Your settlement no longer has an {{TOOL.AXE}} available. You will no longer be able to chop down trees.
More axes can be crafted at the {{FURNITURE.FORGE}}. If you do not have a {{FURNITURE.FORGE}} up and running, you may need to remove a {{FURNITURE.WOODCUTTERS_BENCH}}.
Your settlement no longer has a {{TOOL.CHISEL}} available. This is required to construct stone furniture.
More chisels can be crafted at the {{FURNITURE.FORGE}}. If you do not have a {{FURNITURE.FORGE}} up and running, you may need to remove a {{FURNITURE.STONEMASON_WORKBENCH}}.
Your settlement no longer has a {{TOOL.PLANE}} available. This is required to construct wooden furniture.
More planes can be crafted at the {{FURNITURE.CARPENTRY_WORKBENCH}} from a {{RESOURCE.PLANKS.NOUN}}.
Your settlement no longer has a {{TOOL.SAW}} available. This is required to build a {{FURNITURE.WOODCUTTERS_BENCH}} or {{FURNITURE.CARPENTRY_WORKBENCH}}.

More saws can be crafted at the {{FURNITURE.FORGE}}. If you do not have a {{FURNITURE.FORGE}} up and running, you may need to remove a {{FURNITURE.WOODCUTTERS_BENCH}} or {{FURNITURE.CARPENTRY_WORKBENCH}}.

Welcome to the world of King under the Mountain! This is an early alpha version of the game with many more features and gameplay elements still to be implemented. Your intrepid band of dwarven settlers have chosen this area to found a new colony of their kingdom. Provide food, shelter and prosperity for them and who knows, maybe one day this will be the capital of a kingdom of its own!
Click “Tutorial” to be guided through the basics, “Hints only” to skip the tutorial but be provided with info as you play, or “Disable all hints” to stop showing these messages.
Start the game by selecting a location on the map with enough space, and clicking the '{{GUI.EMBARK.START}}' button.

NOTES: E.g. “Urist McScrooge, insane dwarf”
E.g. “Urist McScrooge, Dwarven miner”
To be combined with the above as “bread dough”
To be combined with the above as “bread loaf”

ENGLISH: This needs to be milled before it can be used further for brewing.
This is combined with water in a {{FURNITURE.MASH_TUN}} to produce {{LIQUID.WORT}}.
Also known as mycelium, this can be thought of as “seeds” from which to grow mushrooms in a {{ROOMS.MUSHROOM_FARM}}.

NOTES: E.g. “Wheat seed”
E.g. “4 wheat seeds”

ENGLISH: Seeds of the right type are required for planting in a {{ROOMS.FARM}}. They also need to be available in a {{STOCKPILE.GRANARY}} stockpile.

NOTES: This is the label of “inventory” to go above a list of items contained within a piece of furniture or held by a character
E.g. “Iron axe”, “Beech wood fishing rod”, “3 marble blocks”
E.g. “2 potatoes”

ENGLISH: Beloved by dwarves, this will provide a substantial happiness bonus for a while. The only problem is that they will eventually require it to get through the working day.
This is the final stage of unfermented beer before it is placed in a {{FERMENTATION_TANK}} to produce drinkable beer.
This is unfermented beer, it requires {{VEGETABLE.HOPS}} to be added in a {{FURNITURE.BREW_KETTLE}} for flavour before it can be fermented.
This settler was so unhappy that they have been pushed past the breaking point and will no longer work or even eat!

NOTES: Used for specifying which material something is made out of
For allowing any kind of material to be used
This is only used as a noun
This is only used as a noun
This isn't actually used in-game yet so won't be combined with other words
For saying something is “made up of seed”
Used to make up “Vegetable soup”

ENGLISH: Bronze is an alloy of copper and tin. It is harder and much more durable than copper alone. (Alloys have not yet been implemented in King under the Mountain)

As well as occuring naturally as {{ORE.NATIVE_COPPER.NOUN}}, it is also easy to smelt from {{ORE.MALACHITE.NOUN}} ore. Copper has many uses, particularly in coinage, though it is not hard enough to create effective weapons.
The king of metals. Although it is not the rarest or most valuable, gold is the most coveted metal by most races – particularly dwarves.
It is a poor military which does not have access to iron. Dwarven metalsmiths know the secrets of working this into {{METAL.STEEL.NOUN}}.
A silver-white metal that is highly resistant to corrosion. Platinum is rarer and therefore more valuable than {{METAL.GOLD.NOUN}}.
Iron turns to rust when exposed to rain for a long period. Eventually this will decay completely!
Like {{METAL.GOLD.NOUN}}, silver is often used for coinage and as solid bars for the trading of wealth.
Far stronger than {{METAL.IRON.NOUN}} which makes for superior weapons and tools, only the dwarves know the secret of creating steel.
Tin can be smelted from {{ORE.CASSITERITE.NOUN}} and alloyed with {{METAL.COPPER.NOUN}} to produce {{METAL.BRONZE.NOUN}}. (Alloys have not yet been implemented in King under the Mountain)
This save file was last used while the following mods were active. These mods are now missing or disabled so the save may not load correctly.

The save file could not be loaded because either it is incompatible with this version of the game, or because some mods have been disabled or removed since this save was last loaded. The following mods were expected but are no longer active:

NOTES: E.g. “Toadstool mushroom”

ENGLISH: Your miners have discovered a new area!
A fire has broken out in your settlement!
All things must come to an end. Your settlement lies abandoned.
The prosperity of your settlement has attracted a number of new immigrants to boost your population.
An area has caved in due to a lack of pillars and supports.
An item or piece of furniture has been destroyed due to prolonged exposure to rain.\nSome materials such as iron and steel should not be left outside for a long period.
A roof has collapsed due to a lack of pillars and supports.
The gruelling hardship has proven to be too much to handle for {{character}}.
Bauxite is the primary ore of aluminium. Unfortunately, a means of aluminium production is yet to be discovered.
This can be converted into {{ORE.COKE.NOUN}} using a {{FURNITURE.COKE_OVEN}}.
An ore that can be smelted to produce {{METAL.TIN.NOUN}}.
Often confused with turquoise, it is actually an ore of {{METAL.COPPER}}.
A refined form of {{ORE.BITUMINOUS_COAL}} which can be used as {{FUEL.SACK}}.
An ore that can be smelted to produce {{METAL.SILVER}}.
An ore that can be smelted to produce {{METAL.IRON}}.
Ilmenite is the primary ore of titanium. Unfortunately, a means of titanium production is yet to be discovered.
An ore that can be smelted to produce {{METAL.COPPER}}.
Naturally-occuring {{METAL.COPPER}} which must be smelted before use.
Naturally-occuring {{METAL.GOLD}} which must be smelted before use.
Naturally-occuring {{METAL.PLATINUM}} which must be smelted before use.
Naturally-occuring {{METAL.SILVER}} which must be smelted before use.
Pollucite is an ore of Caesium, which is currently too dangerous to produce. Particularly crazy dwarven metalsmiths are currently trying to find a reliable method of production.
Also known as Pyrite, its pale-yellow appearance causes some to mistake it for gold. It has several uses when crushed, but care must be taken as it sparks when struck.
A silvery metallic ore which turns black when exposed to air. It is strangely warm to the touch.
A metallic ore which complicates the smelting of tin. It has too high a melting point to be smelted with normal processes.
King under the Mountain is in active development. To help

diagnose and fix bugs, please click "I accept" below to
This is made up of only the following data:
- The version of the game client
- Your graphics card and display settings
A large block of metal used to hammer heated metal into shape. Required to construct a {{FURNITURE.FORGE}.
Metal hoops used to construct a {{PRODUCT.BARREL.NOUN}}. Also used in some machinery.
Curved wooden planks used to construct a {{PRODUCT.BARREL.NOUN}}.
A cylindrical container for liquids. The curved shape makes it easier to roll around.

NOTES: A bowl for eating from
E.g. “Bowl of vegetable soup”

ENGLISH: A mix of ingredients that can be baked into {{PRODUCT.BREAD.LOAF.PLURAL}} using an {{FURNITURE.BAKING_OVEN}}.

NOTES: Translations incorrect and need fixing
Translations incorrect and need fixing

ENGLISH: A small container used to move liquids around by hand.

NOTES: A large metal pot for cooking (common with Halloween)

ENGLISH: Used by a {{PROFESSION.CHEF}} to prepare soup in a {{ROOMS.KITCHEN}}, where it is then moved to a {{ROOMS.FEASTING_HALL}}.
This is a metal container used to store liquids, which must be crafted at the {{FURNITURE.FORGE}}.
Two large stone discs that are ground together to mill harvested crops. Used to construct a {{FURNITURE.FLOUR_MILL}}.
These will last a long time to feed your settlers, but you will need other sources of food as a priority.
Crafts items using metal and also produces metal from ore.
Prepares all of the food to be consumed by your settlers.

NOTES: This could be “fisherman” and “fisherwoman”

ENGLISH: Catches fish from bodies of water for use as food and resources.

NOTES: This could be “huntsman” and “huntress”

ENGLISH: Tracks and kills wild animals for their meat and pelts.

NOTES: In English at least, “mayoress” is incorrect
Not a fully implemented profession, just used to describe “Milling flour”

ENGLISH: Nobles do not fulfil jobs in the same way as common settlers, but bring fame and prestige to your settlement.

NOTES: from “runes” and “blacksmith”
This is an invented term for the game, but should be derived

ENGLISH: Enchants weapons, armour and items with magical runes to boost their abilities.
Crafts furniture and items from stone.
This settler does not have any specific professions and will fulfil any mundane tasks like hauling items.

NOTES: This could be “lumberjack” and “lumberjane”

ENGLISH: Cuts down trees as lumber that can be used in a {{ROOMS.SAWMILL}}.

NOTES: The male and female forms are only for languages that need them
Note that I'm going with Tolkein's spelling of “dwarves” rather than “dwarfs”

ENGLISH: Dwarves are short and stocky humanoids. They are masters of working with stone and metal. Most dwarves distrust the sky and prefer to stay underground.
A salt of sulphuric acid with many uses in industry. (Usages of vitriol are not yet implemented in King under the Mountain)
Grain that has been milled into a fine powder ready to be used as an ingredient in the production of food.
Gems that have been cut and polished to enhance their beauty. Most commonly used as ornamentation.
A hunk of rock containing gems ready to be cut and polished.
Sections of a tree that are most commonly prepared into {{RESOURCE.PLANKS.PLURAL}}, but have other uses as well.
A lump of metal mixed with slag which must be hammered into a usable form.
Refined metal blocks, ready to be used as a crafting ingredient.
Large, flat plates that are used in some of the larger machinery.

A log that has been infused with {{INGREDIENT.MUSHROOM.SPAWN.NOUN}}. The body of the log itself is where the mushrooms draw nutrients from. It requires dousing in a {{FURNITURE.MUSHROOM_SHOCK_TANK}} after becoming fully innoculated.
Sections of a giant mushroom that can be used in the same way as wooden {{RESOURCE.LOGS.PLURAL}}.
A metallic sand created by breaking down raw metal ore, ready for use in a {{FURNITURE.BLOOMERY_FURNACE}}.
Stone that contains metallic ores which can be processed into usable metal.
Sections of wood of a fixed size so they can be easily used in constructions and crafting.
This mushroom-infused log has been “shocked” in water to encourage the mushrooms to develop and should produce a harvest soon.
Stone that has been shaped into a cube so that is can be easily used in construction or crafting.
A huge piece of stone that must be chiselled into a more useful shape by a {{PROFESSION.STONEMASON}}.
A place for your settlers to sleep. They prefer to have individual bedrooms that are at least 9 tiles in size, and preferably at least 13 tiles in size.
Brews beer for your settlers to enjoy! Other alcoholic beverages will be implemented in the future.
Placed across the river to allow access to the other side.
This workshop produces most wooden tools and items.
An outdoor area for large constructions.
Grows crops using {{INGREDIENT.SEEDS.PLURAL}}. Must be placed on {{MATERIAL_TYPE.EARTH.NOUN}}.
A place for settlers to gather to eat, drink and be merry!
Deceased settlers are laid to rest here.
Most food is prepared here before being served in a {{ROOMS.FEASTING_HALL}}.
This workshop produces most items made out of stone.
Metal ore is refined and used in crafting here.
Mushrooms can be grown using {{INGREDIENT.MUSHROOM.SPAWN.NOUN}} and wooden {{RESOURCE.LOGS.PLURAL}}.
This area stores different kinds of items depending on settings.
Unused items are placed in stockpiles for easy access.
These are the remains of an item that has completed corroded due to rust.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.BARLEY.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A grain used only in the production of beer. Can be planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}}, {{SEASON.SUMMER}} or {{SEASON.AUTUMN}}.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.BERSERKER_MUSHROOM.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A mushroom with a pink-red cap bearing white spots. It has hallucinogenic properties which warriors sometimes use in preparation for battle.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.CARROT.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A hardy root vegetable that survives the {{SEASON.WINTER}} frost. Carrots grow quickly but only produce a small crop. Can be planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}}, {{SEASON.SUMMER}} or {{SEASON.AUTUMN}}.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.CORN.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A cereal grain also known as maize. It produces a bountiful crop but takes around 2 seasons to grow and can not survive {{SEASON.WINTER}}, so it requires planting in early {{SEASON.SPRING}}.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.DEATH_CAP_MUSHROOM.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A very poisonous mushroom with a wide, flat cap. Eating even a tiny amount will almost certainly cause poisoning which can lead to death.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.ELFSBANE_MUSHROOM.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: This mushroom has a simple, flavourless taste to most humanoids. Strangely, it tastes absolutely disgusting to elves, who often react with explosive vomiting upon consumption, or in extreme cases, a heart attack.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.FIST_MUSHROOM.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A black-blue mushroom with a metallic taste. It is named for a group of bards from the age of darkness.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.GLOW_MUSHROOM.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A magic-infused mushroom that gives off light and changes colour with the seasons.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.HOPS.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A flower used for the flavouring of beer. Must be planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}}.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.MILTONIA_MUSHROOM.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: Once thought to exist only in the Hudds region, it is now found throughout the world.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.POTATO.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A starchy root vegetable which can survive {{SEASON.WINTER}} making it a good choice for most settlements. Can be planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}}, {{SEASON.SUMMER}} or {{SEASON.AUTUMN}}.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.PURPLE_HELMET_MUSHROOM.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: Fat Hat, Plump Turban, Puffy Helmet; This fabled mushroom goes by many names. Legend holds that long ago, many communities of dwarves subsisted entirely on a domesticated strain of this fungus.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.ROCIOMYCOTA_MUSHROOM.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A white and black spotted mushroom. It has been known to affect the appearance of those who ingest it.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.SUNGLOW_MUSHROOM.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A bright yellow mushroom which glows with the appearance of sunlight. It loses this glow the moment it is harvested.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.SYRUP_POWDER_MUSHROOM.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A round orange/yellow mushroom with a white underside. It is said to have been used by mages long ago, but for what purpose, nobody knows.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.TOMATO.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A plant which grows large red berries often used as a vegetable. Can only be planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}}.

NOTES: {{VEGETABLE.WHEAT.TOOLTIP}}
ENGLISH: A cereal grain generally used for the production of bread. It can survive {{SEASON.WINTER}} but takes a while to grow, so it is either planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}} or {{SEASON.AUTUMN}}.

NOTES: Shrub or bush should do

ENGLISH: Stores harvested fruit and vegetables which can expire.
Stores grains and seeds which will not expire.
Stores tools required for working on jobs.
An igneous rock formed by the rapid cooling of lava. Almost all of the volcanic rock in the world is basalt.
A sedimentary rock mostly made up of the mineral dolomite, so it is also known as dolomite rock.
A blue-hued rock mostly found on an icy island to the north. It has a high iron content.
A common type of igneous rock. It has a large proportion of quartz, making it good for locating certain gemstones.
A lightly-coloured sedimentary rock which makes for a good building material. It is also used as a flux in the production of {{METAL.STEEL.NOUN}}.
A metamorphic rock which is used as a high-quality material for sculpture and masonry due to its brilliant appearance.
A sedimentary rock composed of sand-like fragments.
A fine-grained sedimentary rock composed of pressurized mud. It can be easily broken into thin layers.
A metamorphic rock that is usually formed out of {{STONE.SHALE.NOUN}}. It is often made into tiles for roofing or writing.
Used to chop down trees. The primary tool of a {{PROFESSION.WOODCUTTER}}.
Used to sculpt rock into shape. One of the tools used by a {{PROFESSION.STONEMASON}}.
Used to catch fish from a body of water. The primary tool of a {{PROFESSION.FISHER}}.
Used to prepare food, particularly meat.
Used to bash large items of stone and metal into shape. The primary tool of a {{PROFESSION.BLACKSMITH}}.
Used to break stone into smaller pieces. The primary tool of a {{PROFESSION.MiNER}}.

NOTES: A carpenter's plane

ENGLISH: Used to shave wooden furniture and items into shape. The primary tool of a {{PROFESSION.CARPENTER}}.
Used to prepare dough. One of the tools used by a {{PROFESSION.CHEF}}.

NOTES: A carpenter's saw

ENGLISH: Used to cut wood into shape. Required for cutting lumber in the {{ROOMS.SAWMILL}}.
Used to bash small items of stone and metal into shape. One of the tools used by a {{PROFESSION.BLACKSMITH}}.

NOTES: A blacksmith's tongs

ENGLISH: Used to hold extremely hot metal items. Used in the process of smelting metal ore.

NOTES: E.g. “Oak tree”

ENGLISH: Your settlers have three basic needs to fulfil: food, drink and somewhere to sleep. Although they will complain about it for now, they can drink from the nearby river and sleep on the ground. What they can’t do is magic up some food from nowhere (at least, not without a mage around!) so we will focus on food to begin with.

The first thing you should do each spring is ensure that enough crops have been planted for the harvest in autumn. Farming is a reliable and sustainable food source, but you need to make sure you have enough crops to feed your population between each annual harvest.

A good rule of thumb to follow is to ensure you have 10 tiles of crops being sown for each settler in your population. Currently there are 7 settlers milling around, so go ahead and click “{{GUI.ZONES_LABEL}}” > “{{ROOMS.FARM}}”, and designate / drag out several farm plots on a grassy area.

With nothing else to do, your settlers will start preparing these {{ROOMS.FARM.PLURAL}} by tilling the earth to be ready for seeds to be sown. This doesn’t require any special tools or knowledge so everyone should get involved.

This prepares the plot to be sown, but you need to select which crop to grow on each farm plot before a farmer will come and plant the relevant seeds. Your settlers have brought with them a selection of different seeds. You can click “Resources” in the upper-right to get a breakdown of all the items in your settlement.

For the seeds to actually be available to your farmers, they need to be in a stockpile compared to being held in a dwarf’s inventory like they are currently. Click {{GUI.ZONES_LABEL}} > {{ROOMS.STOCKPILES}} > {{STOCKPILE.GROUP.SEEDS}} (you can right-click to go back up to a previous menu) and designate an area to be used for seeds to be stored.

Your settlers have also brought a bunch of tools with them what will need moving around. From {{ROOMS.STOCKPILES}} also choose {{STOCKPILE.GROUP.TOOLS}} and designate another area to be used to store tools.
After some time your settlers should put items they are not using into stockpiles, like the seeds that are to be sown.

Left-click on each of the {{ROOMS.FARM.PLURAL}} and select a crop to be planted there. Don’t select {{VEGETABLE.BARLEY}} or {{VEGETABLE.HOPS}} for now, as these crops are used in the production of beer, not food.

Your {{PROFESSION.FARMER.PLURAL}} will now get to work sowing the seeds you have selected to these {{ROOMS.FARM.PLURAL}}. Sowing seeds does not require any special tools but you might want to assign more settlers as {{PROFESSION.FARMER.PLURAL}}. Left-click on a settler who is wandering around aimlessly.

Clicking on a settler lets you see their name, professions, inventory, needs and happiness. Click on the blank square button next to their other professions to set a 3rd and final profession as a {{PROFESSION.FARMER.NOUN}}.

Note that some jobs require the settler to have a specific tool in their inventory, and if none are available in the settlement they won’t work on the jobs that require it. For example, you can assign more settlers as a {{PROFESSION.WOODCUTTER}}, but they can’t chop down trees without an available {{TOOL.AXE.NOUN}}.

Your crops will now grow and eventually be harvested by your {{PROFESSION.FARMER.PLURAL}} in the {{SEASON.AUTUMN}}. Some crops can be planted again later in the year and survive through the {{SEASON.WINTER}}, but some do not. To get the most out of your crops, it is best to produce soup from the vegetables harvested, or bread from grain.

Let’s get a {{ROOMS.KITCHEN}} set up to produce soup once your crops are ready. Go to the top level menu then {{GUI.ZONES_LABEL}} > {{ROOMS.KITCHEN}} and drag out a {{ROOMS.KITCHEN}} area. For now you can build this outside, but you will eventually want to move the majority of your work areas inside for protection from the elements.

Unlike farm plots, kitchens (and most other rooms) need furniture to function. Click “Furniture” when you have placed a kitchen zone and you’ll be presented with the furniture that can be added. To produce soup, you need to build a {{FURNITURE.WATER_BARREL}}, {{FURNITURE.KITCHEN_WORKTOP}} and {{FURNITURE.CAULDRON}} in the same kitchen zone. Also, designate a {{STOCKPILE.GROUP.FOOD}} {{ROOMS.STOCKPILE}} to store any harvested crops.

When your crops have been harvested, cooks will bring vegetables to the {{FURNITURE.KITCHEN_WORKTOP}} before adding them to the {{FURNITURE.CAULDRON}} with water and producing soup! Making soup and baking bread means your food supplies will go much further - a single vegetable will feed a dwarf for a single meal, but 3 vegetables cooked into soup will provide 12 meals!

Eventually this kitchen will produce a cauldron full of steaming hot soup, but the cooks don’t like other dwarves getting in the way in their kitchen, so instead you need to have the soup brought to a feasting hall for the whole settlement to enjoy. Designate a feasting hall by clicking on {{GUI.ZONES_LABEL}} > {{ROOMS.FEASTING_HALL}}, then add a {{FURNITURE.CAULDRON}} to it. Note that a feasting hall cauldron won’t be placed until a cauldron containing thick, delicious soup is available.

Over time you will want to expand your food production but this will keep our small settlement nourished for the upcoming winter - your settlers have brought rations to sustain them while the first crops grow.

Most items and furniture are produced out of {{MATERIAL_TYPE.WOOD.ADJECTIVE}} {{RESOURCE.PLANKS.PLURAL}} or {{MATERIAL_TYPE.STONE.ADJECTIVE}} {{RESOURCE.STONE.BLOCK.PLURAL}}. It’s important to maintain a large supply of these. {{MATERIAL_TYPE.WOOD.ADJECTIVE}} {{RESOURCE.PLANKS.PLURAL}} are produced in a {{ROOMS.SAWMILL}}, and {{MATERIAL_TYPE.STONE.ADJECTIVE}} {{RESOURCE.STONE.BLOCK.PLURAL}} are crafted by a {{PROFESSION.STONEMASON}} in a {{ROOMS.MASONRY_WORKSHOP}}. Place one of each of these zones, and build a {{FURNITURE.WOODCUTTERS_BENCH}} and {{FURNITURE.STONEMASON_WORKBENCH}} in them.

Now you are ready to produce {{MATERIAL_TYPE.WOOD.ADJECTIVE}} {{RESOURCE.PLANKS.PLURAL}} and {{MATERIAL_TYPE.STONE.ADJECTIVE}} {{RESOURCE.STONE.BLOCK.PLURAL}}, but they require other resources to craft them - {{MATERIAL_TYPE.WOOD.ADJECTIVE}} {{RESOURCE.LOGS.PLURAL}} and {{RESOURCE.STONE.UNREFINED.PLURAL}}. Fortunately these can usually be harvested from the game world quite easily.

Select {{GUI.ORDERS_LABEL}} > {{GUI.ORDERS.CHOP_WOOD}} and click-and-drag over trees to let your woodcutters know to cut them down. Similarly you can select select {{GUI.ORDERS_LABEL}} > {{GUI.ORDERS.MINE}} and click-and-drag an area of the mountain to designate to be mined. Select enough of both to build your stockpiles back up to 40 of each.
Be careful with mining! A mined-out area of 7 by 7 tiles without a {{FURNITURE.PILLAR}} built within that area will collapse!
You can use the W, A, S and D keys or the arrow keys to pan the camera around. Moving the cursor to the edge of the screen also pans the camera, but this can be disabled in the options menu.
Scrolling the mouse wheel or pressing the Q and E keys zooms the camera in or out.
In the lower-right section of the screen is the minimap, and you can click on this to jump the camera to that point. Click on the “Minimap” label to show or hide the minimap.
Try out these camera controls and then click “Next” to proceed.

This covers the basics of playing King under the Mountain. For your next challenge, aim to set up a functioning {{ROOMS.METALWORKS}} with a {{FURNITURE.FORGE}} provided with fuel and refined metal ore. Refined metal ores are produced at the {{FURNITURE.ORE_CRUSHING_STATION}}, and fuel can be crushed from coal or produced out of {{MATERIAL_TYPE.WOOD.ADJECTIVE}} {{RESOURCE.LOGS.PLURAL}} with a {{FURNITURE.CHARCOAL_CLAMP}} in an {{ROOMS.EARTHWORKS}}. Good luck!

NOTES: Used to show a progress indicator for how many farm plots have a crop selected e.g. 2 of 10 farm plots with a crop assigned
Used to show a progress indicator for how many of a certain profession have been assigned e.g. 2 of 10 farmers assigned
Used to show a progress indicator in the form: 2 of 10 stone blocks
Used to show a progress indicator for a certain number of tiles e.g. 2 of 10 farm plot tiles

ENGLISH: Your progress is saved automatically at midnight, and also whenever you exit the game. You can also quicksave by pressing the F5 key.
The upper-right section of the screen shows the current date and time, and has controls for the game speed.
You can press the spacebar to pause or unpause the game.

The 1 key sets the game to run at normal speed, while the 2, 3 and 4 keys make the game run at an increasingly faster pace. The game will automatically jump to speed 4 while all your settlers are asleep.
You can also click the speed icons to change the speed or pause the game.
A grain used only in the production of beer. Can be planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}}, {{SEASON.SUMMER}} or {{SEASON.AUTUMN}}.
A mushroom with a pink-red cap bearing white spots. It has hallucinogenic properties which warriors sometimes use in preparation for battle.
A hardy root vegetable that survives the {{SEASON.WINTER}} frost. Carrots grow quickly but only produce a small crop. Can be planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}}, {{SEASON.SUMMER}} or {{SEASON.AUTUMN}}.
A cereal grain also known as maize. It produces a bountiful crop but takes around 2 seasons to grow and can not survive {{SEASON.WINTER}}, so it requires planting in early {{SEASON.SPRING}}.
A very poisonous mushroom with a wide, flat cap. Eating even a tiny amount will almost certainly cause poisoning which can lead to death.

This mushroom has a simple, flavourless taste to most humanoids. Strangely, it tastes absolutely disgusting to elves, who often react with explosive vomiting upon consumption, or in extreme cases, a heart attack.

A magic-infused mushroom that gives off light and changes colour with the seasons.
A flower used for the flavouring of beer. Must be planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}}.
Once thought to exist only in the Hudds region, it is now found throughout the world.
A starchy root vegetable which can survive {{SEASON.WINTER}} making it a good choice for most settlements. Can be planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}}, {{SEASON.SUMMER}} or {{SEASON.AUTUMN}}.

A white and black spotted mushroom. It has been known to affect the appearance of those who ingest it.
A bright yellow mushroom which glows with the appearance of sunlight. It loses this glow the moment it is harvested.
A round orange/yellow mushroom with a white underside. It is said to have been used by mages long ago, but for what purpose, nobody knows.
A plant which grows large red berries often used as a vegetable. Can only be planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}}.
A cereal grain generally used for the production of bread. It can survive {{SEASON.WINTER}} but takes a while to grow, so it is either planted in {{SEASON.SPRING}} or {{SEASON.AUTUMN}}.
Also known as iron sulfate, this salt has several uses, including as a soil additive to improve crop farming. (Usages of vitriol are not yet implemented in King under the Mountain)

NOTES: E.g. “Granite rock wall”, “Granite smooth stone wall”
